question: S'happenin, Doc?
answer: Hey, I got it all right here, my man. Jus be waitin on you.

question: We ain't got far to go.
answer: This early bird shit just ain't my style.

question: Everybody on your toes.
answer: Their Right Field's Clear. Those painters are out of the way.

question: What the hell you talking about?
answer: We got a painting crew of painters just went in the building next door.

question: Did you?
answer: I was on another doorway...

question: But you saw the action?
answer: I saw him fall.

question: And the kid was armed?
answer: That's the way it went down.

question: And you saw the weapon?
answer: Yes sir. I saw it in his hand.

question: I ain't got no time to nursmaid a rookie. I don't need a partner.
answer: Your right! You don't need a partner! You need a goddamn keeper! Jesus Christ! How do I explain this one upstairs? We gave you 600 man-hours, you took a month planning the damn thing, and what have you got to show for it? Nine bodies? A dead informant? One of my best men shot! For Christ's sake! You're going to have me back on a beat busting perverts in the park.

question: We got a bigger problem. These Comachos aren't gonna take this lying down. The animals are out of the cages.
answer: Just what I need. A goddman war. Keep track of this business with Cragie?

question: Yeah.
answer: I'll deal with upstairs. Just get me some answers, huh.

question: No! Mama! Daddy, would you get that! Keep 'em closed now. O.K., open 'em. Happy birthday, momma.
answer: Molly! Pack me a bag! Quick! Ok? C'mon I'm in a hurry! Business! C'mon, move. Do what I tell you!

question: Don't do it, momma! Make him pack his own bag.
answer: I ain't got time to put up with your bullshit today.

question: Listen goddammit! It's momma's birthday! She deserves better'n this!
answer: Victor Comacho is alive.

question: You can't go now.
answer: Shut up! Put someone on the house. And you keep an eye on her. What Felix don't know doesn't hurt him. Here. Happy birthday.

question: Later, Odell. It's been a rough one. Bow to your master. Hey, Odell. Here, make yourself crazy.
answer: You look like shit.

question: Thanks, pal.
answer: They had a shot on the tube of you guys comin' out in front of the building. How's Donato?

question: Pissed cause he lost a shoe. Luis Comacho is in town.
answer: He'll collect himself some scalps before this one's over. Your answering machine is on the fritz again. Some woman with a fantastic voice was callin' about comin' over this weekend ta help you with somthin', and then the tape went nuts.

question: Want somthin' to drink?
answer: Does the Pope shit in the woods? Is a bear Catholic?

question: I hate smart ass kids.
answer: Gonna get down in the 30's tonight. Your pilot light is out.

question: I've been told that more than once.
answer: So, who you figure pulled out the rug? Gypsies? Mob?

question: Somebody knew what they were doin'. They blew the top off an anthill.
answer: I'd figure the Mob but Scalese ain't that stupid. Hah! Sombody put the valve in backwards. There. Heat.

question: What was the Cubs final score?
answer: 8 to 1. Machines just don't like you.

question: Maybe I don't like machines.
answer: He's talking about you, Cusack. Pay attention. You're all gonna have to be qualified on this. It's the future.

question: Just what the world needs, another gun without a brain.
answer: You're looking at the perfect cop. The damn thing follows orders.

question: Eenie Verona is the gentleman's name. You did a hell of a job on him.
answer: I was motivated.

question: Know him?
answer: He's a punk. Punk thief. Booster.

question: Looks like he graduated.
answer: He had a brother-in-law. They were tight. Served time together. Ganelli..., Gagleone...

question: This Ganiani's a swinger, huh?
answer: He's just makin' up for the time he spent in the joint.

question: Now what? They selling protection to the bears?
answer: Relax kid.

question: What's this? Kinda young for that old fart ain't she?
answer: Just watch, kid. Learn.

question: Wanna play ball?
answer: Are you pitching?

question: Some people say I've got a pretty good inside curve.
answer: I don't know. You look strictly minor league.

question: I'm Eddie.
answer: I make it Eddie-The-Cop.

question: You've had a lot of experience with cops?
answer: All bad.

question: You'll get slivers.
answer: Hey, what the hell do you think you're doing?

question: I thought you knew all about cops. You don't put anything up your nose do you? Diana Luna? You're Tony Luna's daughter?
answer: I don't know where he is, and I don't really give a shit. When are you people going to realize I don't have anything to do with my father.

question: For when you need a friend.
answer: I've got all the friends I want.

question: Say, partner.
answer: How ya doing, Richie?

question: Swinging. How's this? Two G's, we get a sausage and beef stand stand outside Wrigley Field. You pass the beef, I take the cash. Free games. I got a contact downtown.
answer: How you gonna watch the game if you're hawking sandwiches?

question: Hey, Cusack. How about taking the gloves off long enough to sign this for Cragie.
answer: This about the hearing?

question: You bet.
answer: I pass.

question: What the fuck's the matter with you?
answer: He's burnt, Brennan, and you know it. He was a good cop, but he ain't now.

question: Get off your high horse, Cusack. He made a couple of mistakes, OK. The guy was a hero. What the fuck does a bunch of civilians know about comin' up some shithouse stairway day after day, scared outta your shorts.
answer: We're all scared, Brennan. Cragie should have been off the street a long time ago. He's gonna hurt somebody else with his bullshit. Maybe even you.

question: Stay by the radio.
answer: The modern age's answer to the crystal ball. Marvelous. If you know how to read it. Listen. If you have some extra cash, buy oranges. The price is low, and I can promise you the threatened trucking strike will be avoided.

question: We talking about a bribe, Scalese?
answer: It's a prediction. No. I wouldn't try to bribe Eddie Cusack. You're incorruptible. Untarnished. I hear they call you stainless steel on the street. Me, I think you're a fuckin' pain in the ass.

question: Thanks.
answer: It's not a compliment.

question: I'm looking for your nephew.
answer: Tony? Forget it. Tony Luna's none of your business.

question: Wrong. Tony just made himself my business.
answer: No he didn't. We take care of our own. Just like the cops. Just like the Comachos. You understand.

question: He shit on my turf, old man. And I'm going to nail him and anybody else tied to him. You understand, Felix?
answer: Nobody threatens Felix Scalese.

question: Pompas, you're getting to be a fucking pain in the ass. Let her go, pooch. You don't have the balls.
answer: Where are you taking me?

question: Downtown first. Then I'm gonna place you in protective custody.
answer: The hell you are!

question: You'll be safe --
answer: I'll take my chances.

question: Keep your goddamn pants on! This your idea of a social call?
answer: Fred Pirelli, this is Diana. Diana Luna.

question: C'mon, kid. Let's get you off your feet.
answer: Can you put her up till I find her old man?

question: Does a bear...?
answer: Am I putting you on the spot?

question: Beer? Looks like I'm caught between the rock and the hard place, Sarge. You know I really wanted to be a good cop, but... shit. It's hard enough sometimes just to stay alive. Comes so easy to you. You got all the fuckin' answers. Me, I'm still tryin' to find the questions. Cragie planted the gun on the kid. Just wasted him, and then I... I don't know what to do about the hearing tomorrow...
answer: Tell the truth.

question: See. It's all so nothin' for you. If I talk straight every cop on the force will shit on me. If I don't... Cragie gets away with murder.
answer: And the chance to do it again. Next time he might take away a cop. That make any difference?

question: He's my partner.
answer: Your partner's selling you out, Kosalas. He kills an unarmed kid, and now he's risking your ass to save his own.

question: It was a mistake.
answer: It cost an innocent kid his life.

question: I know that! I KNOW THAT! Jesus. I see that kid's face every time I close my eyes.
answer: Tell 'em like it is, Nick. I'll back you up.

question: Tell 'em like it is, Nick. I'll back you up.
answer: Nice to see you out with the boys for a change, Sarge.

question: Hello, Cragie.
answer: They tell me my Sergeant wouldn't sign for me. You want to tell me why?

question: You know why.
answer: No. Tell me.

question: You were a good cop for a lot of years. You've passed your limit now Cragie.
answer: Fuck you. Where do you get off?

question: Officer Cragie has already been sworn. Officer Cragie, you have heard Mrs. Murillio's testimony --
answer: Yes, sir.

question: You have heard her tell this panel that she saw you lay the gun in her grandson's hand.
answer: I'm not saying the woman would make this up. But there's no way she could have seen anything from where she was standing in a hallway that dark. Like you said, she's the boy's grandmother.

question: If it was dark, Officer, how were you sure Vega had a gun?
answer: We were lucky. There was a glint of light, a reflection comin off the barrel of the weapon.

question: And right after you heard Officer Cragie's gun discharge, what did you do then?
answer: I immediately advanced down the hall.

question: And what did you see?
answer: The deceased, Vega, lying on the floor. Officer Cragie was checking his vital signs.

question: What happened then?
answer: We recovered a .25 calibre automatic from the teenager's right hand.

question: Did you see that weapon in Vega's hand before Officer Cragie fired?
answer: Yes, sir.

question: I can't comment on that. It was over before I got there.
answer: You are his superior officer, are you not?

question: Cragie's in my unit, yes.
answer: Did you give the men their various assignments?

question: I did.
answer: Did you request that officer Cragie be on your TAC team?

question: No, I didn't.
answer: Sergeant... I have here a department document dated 24 September, of last year. It is a request by you, to your superiors, to have Officer Cragie transferred to another unit. Are you familiar with this document?

question: Yes.
answer: Why did you request his transfer?

question: Maybe 30 years is too long for anyone to look at the city's guts, Mr. Partida.
answer: What happened to this request?

question: It was denied.
answer: This is a letter of support for Officer Cragie. Everyone in his unit signed it but you. Why?

question: I don't agree with what it says.
answer: Are you saying you do not believe Officer Cragie is fit to work the streets of Chicago?

question: I would have been here, Sarge. They kept it from me.
answer: You're Ok, Hopalong.

question: Listen, I'm havin' a drink with this friend of mine, name of Mickie. She works on a computer over in the Federal Building, FBI. I got here as soon as I heard.
answer: They got Diana Luna.

question: I can't swallow this shit! Eddie Cusack's out there takin' on the world by himself. And you fuckin' heros are gonna sit on your goddamn asses!
answer: Cool it kid.

question: Don't you fuckin' tell me to cool it. I won't cool it. I'm not going to fuckin' lie for you any more. I lied, Commander. He laid a gun on that kid. I saw the whole thing.
answer: You little fuckin' bastard!
